urls.title: FOSI | Making Sense of Age Assurance: Enabling Safer Online Experiences
urls.description: Age assurance has been a key challenge for online platforms and services for many years. While it is agreed that keeping children in age-appropriate spaces is a fundamental part of their safety, assessing age and implementing solutions is still an area that parents, companies, and governments are working to address. This report examines the awareness, attitudes, and behaviors of both parents and children regarding age assurance – a process that encompasses the methods and solutions used to verify or

tweets.text:
🤔How do we #design #rights respecting #EdTech #data for the future?💻

Find out from the authors of our new essay collection, Education Data Futures ➡️Sign up here: https://t.co/ZhlNCYEn00

and see you on Monday! #DigitalFutures #EdTech #worldchildrensday @5RightsFound @MediaLSE https://t.co/ye3HedobBb

urls.title: Welcome! You are invited to join a webinar: Digital Futures Commission | Education data futures launch. After registering, you will receive a confirmation email about joining the webinar.
urls.description: Join us on World Children’s Day for the virtual launch of our new essay collection by regulators, specialists and academics on the problems and possibilities for children’s education data. Baroness Beeban Kidron and Professor Sonia Livingstone LSE will be joined by a selection of authors from the essay collection. We do hope you will be able to join us, and please do feel free to forward this invitation to anyone in your network who may be interested in attending. If you have any questions about the event or the Digital Futures Commission, please get in touch with us at info@5rightsfoundation.com.

urls.description: Age assurance has been a key challenge for online platforms and services for many years. While it is agreed that keeping children in age-appropriate spaces is a fundamental part of their safety, assessing age and implementing solutions is still an area that parents, companies, and governments are working to address. This report examines the awareness, attitudes, and behaviors of both parents and children regarding age assurance – a process that encompasses the methods and solutions used to verify or

tweets.text:
Platform democracy can also help address both platform power and partisan political pressure.
Platform elections are probably a terrible idea.

But there are new democratic approaches that *can* work for platforms, and @ClaudiaChwalisz (OECD) will join us to explore those.

I mean... We went from "power to the people" to "there is no choice but for Twitter to be the final arbiter" in like a week and a half of confusion.

Maybe next time you burn billions, take a minute to understand why the business you bought operates the way it does. https://t.co/yn7ymaa3nL

tweets.text: The Digital Literacy Curriculum in Chicago and Los Angeles Schools project is a partnership with the nation's 2nd and 3rd largest districts to develop digital literacy materials to embed in specific subject areas. @SHEG_Stanford @samwineburg @anterobot  https://t.co/z0NmRQkCm2

urls.title: Digital Literacy Curriculum in Chicago and Los Angeles Schools | Impact Labs
urls.description: Young people meet the world through the internet. But the dominant approaches for teaching digital literacy are woefully outdated (think: antiquated checklists that tell students that websites ending in .org are more trustworthy and that a site is credible if it lists a contact address). Dated strategies make students vulnerable to bad actors, who exploit easily-gamed signals of credibility. A national survey by the Stanford History Education Group showed that high school students struggle to perform

tweets.text: Facebook Doesn’t Care About Our Kids: What Parents Can Do https://t.co/NKwumDYhUh

urls.title: Is Instagram bad for kids? What parents can do
urls.description: Does Instagram hurt kids? My answer...It depends. Recently some very concerning research showing Instagram can be particularly toxic for teenage girls came to light. This confirms parents suspected about kids' experiences with Instagram. The current Senate hearing is asking Facebook to respond to these revelations. Despite all of this, I don’t recommend that parents shut kids off from all social media until they are 18. Teaching kids the ropes of social media is going to be more effective than preaching abstinence-only.
